observations: The task involves filling enclosed areas of color 0 (background) with color 4 (yellow), where the boundaries are formed by color 3 (green).
An enclosed area is defined by 0-cells that cannot reach the edge of the grid moving only through other 0-cells in a 4-connected manner (up, down, left, right).
Examples show both single-cell holes and multi-cell rectangular or irregular holes being filled with 4.
hypotheses: Identify all 0-cells that are not connected to the grid boundary via other 0-cells. Change these 0-cells to 4.
Identify every cell with value 0 that is surrounded by value 3 in its direct 4-neighborhood. Change these cells to 4. (Rejected: Example 3 and 4 show larger areas are filled, not just single cells).
Perform a flood fill from the edges of the grid starting at all 0-cells on the boundary. Any 0-cell not reached by the flood fill and not colored 3 should be colored 4.

rejected_hypotheses.hypothesis: Identify every cell with value 0 that is surrounded by value 3 in its direct 4-neighborhood. Change these cells to 4.
rejected_hypotheses.reason: Examples 3 and 4 show large internal rectangular holes are filled, which contains 0-cells that are adjacent to other 0-cells, not just 3s.

selected_rule: Identify all 0-cells that are trapped within boundaries of 3s and cannot reach the grid edge. Change these 0-cells to 4.
step_plan: Scan the input grid to locate all 0-cells that form 'holes' (enclosed spaces).
Use a flood-fill algorithm starting from all boundary 0-cells to mark all 'external' 0-cells.
Any 0-cell that remains unmarked after the flood fill (and is not a 3) is internal/enclosed.
Change the value of these internal 0-cells to 4 in the output grid.
Keep all 3-cells and external 0-cells as they are.
